FacilityName: City of Washington Regional Water Treatment Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
City of Washington
Washington, NC

WTP Chlorine Executive Summary

The City of Washington continues to implement a comprehensive program to safely manage chlorine at its Regional Water Treatment Plant. Chlorine is used as part of the water treatment process. The plant is located just off Highway 264 across from the Beaufort County Community College. There have been no chlorine incidents or accidents in the most recent Five-Year history period.

The Process Safety Management (PSM) that was completed in 1996 has been maintained current for the past five years. The PSM compliance also demonstrates our compliance with the Risk Management Program (RMP) Prevention Program. Key activities have included:

oAn annual review of  all chlorine, PSM and RMP procedures
oThree Year Refreshed training conducted on November 14, 2003
oA Process Hazards Analysis conducted on December 15, 2000 
oSelf Audits every three years with the last one on May 12, 2004
oA comprehensive Mechanical Integrity program that uses a computer-based maintenance scheduling program
oAn annual review and update of the Emergency Response Plan including periodic drills with the Washington Fire/Rescue Department

In addition to these compliance activities, the City of Washington has implemented these chlorine safety controls

oThe plant computerized SCADA system monitors the chemical release alarms 24 hours a day
oAny active mitigation would be applied by the Haz-Mat team and support personnel of the Washington Fire/Rescue Department. 

Within the Utilities department, there are monthly safety meeting to review an OSHA subject or discuss a safety issue. Routine training is conducted for topics such as:

oHazard Communications
oPersonal Protective Equipment
oLockout/Tagout
oSite Security
oConfined Space


As a result of our programs, the plant has had an excellent safety record. We plan to continue our emphasis on safety to maintain and improve our safety performance.

Report by:
Stephen Adam Waters II 
Superintendent Water Resources
